goal.ch:
Algorithms is Mathematics in action, and it takes Mathematics to justify Algorithms.

This is a serious course about computer algorithms. From a practical perspective, we study the design and analysis of classical algorithms. Students will learn to come up with algorithms to solve new problems, prove the correctness of the algorithms, and analyze the run time and required memory space of the algorithms.

Traditionally, computer algorithms are more ``discrete‘‘ than ``continuous‘‘ in nature. Therefore this course overlaps more with courses like Discrete Mathematics and Graph Theory than with Calculus and Real Analysis. 

We will not require students to program. However, it takes non-Matlab coding skills listed below to see why we want to study Algorithm. For example, for students to appreciate why we care about memory space usage they have to know how arrays work beyond the point of mere variables in Matlab. Similarly, experience in recursive programming is essential in understanding many classical algorithms like Merge Sort, Quick Sort, etc.


Prerequisites:
-Logical reasoning, non-Matlab coding experience including recursive programming and use of array, Mathematical induction, basic probability
goal.en:
Algorithms is Mathematics in action, and it takes Mathematics to justify Algorithms.

This is a serious course about computer algorithms. From a practical perspective, we study the design and analysis of classical algorithms. Students will learn to come up with algorithms to solve new problems, prove the correctness of the algorithms, and analyze the run time and required memory space of the algorithms.

Traditionally, computer algorithms are more ``discrete‘‘ than ``continuous‘‘ in nature. Therefore this course overlaps more with courses like Discrete Mathematics and Graph Theory than with Calculus and Real Analysis. 

We will not require students to program. However, it takes non-Matlab coding skills listed below to see why we want to study Algorithm. For example, for students to appreciate why we care about memory space usage they have to know how arrays work beyond the point of mere variables in Matlab. Similarly, experience in recursive programming is essential in understanding many classical algorithms like Merge Sort, Quick Sort, etc.


Prerequisites:
-Logical reasoning, non-Matlab coding experience including recursive programming and use of array, Mathematical induction, basic probability

outline.ch:
-Syllabus, what is algorithm, big-O notation, insertion sort, divide-and-conquer, merge sort
-Strassen‘s algorithm, solving recurrences
-Heapsort, Quicksort
-Sorting in linear time, medians and order statistics
-Hash tables, Binary Search Trees (BST)
-Dynamic Programming (DP), greedy algorithms
-Elementary graph algorithms
-Minimum Spanning Trees (MST), Single-Source Shortest Paths (SSSP)
-All-Pairs Shortest Paths (APSP), Maximum flow
-Number-theoretic algorithms, string matching
-NP-completeness, approximation algorithms
outline.en:
-Syllabus, what is algorithm, big-O notation, insertion sort, divide-and-conquer, merge sort
-Strassen‘s algorithm, solving recurrences
-Heapsort, Quicksort
-Sorting in linear time, medians and order statistics
-Hash tables, Binary Search Trees (BST)
-Dynamic Programming (DP), greedy algorithms
-Elementary graph algorithms
-Minimum Spanning Trees (MST), Single-Source Shortest Paths (SSSP)
-All-Pairs Shortest Paths (APSP), Maximum flow
-Number-theoretic algorithms, string matching
-NP-completeness, approximation algorithms

textbook.ch: Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein. Introduction to algorithms. MIT press, 2022.
textbook.en: Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein. Introduction to algorithms. MIT press, 2022.
